title: I’m being sued by Chase Bank. Midland Funding LLC has taken over the suit. It is for about $9,000.
question: I have been on permanent disability for two years now and can’t afford to pay them. They want nearly $7,000 cash or a down payment of $1,000 and payments of $240 a month for 80 months. I can’t afford it. I have almost lost my home to Chase Bank. I’m underwater by $100,000 and paid the other cards I had off, but by settling with them for this one, I ran out of money.
answers:
You need to file an answer to the complaint in order to prevent them from taking a default against you.

You may need to consider bankruptcy.

When you fill out the Answer, type your name in #2, check box 3a (general denial), and check box 6b (prayer for costs of suit). Then go to your local public law library and research affirmative defenses applicable to breach of contract and common counts lawsuits. (I don't know which causes of action plaintiff filed in your case.)

One affirmative defense should be "Plaintiff lacks standing to sue." Then list those affirmative defenses in #4 in the Answer. Last, fill in #1 and type and sign your name on the bottom. Have someone mail a copy of the answer to the plaintiff's attorney and then sign a proof of service (the CA courts website has a POS form). Then file with the court your original answer with attached original POS.
Check with your nearest bankruptcy lawyer. Avoid all the trouble of trying to defend the lawsuit. Get rid of the debt forever.

The information that you put in your question is not really relevant to defending the case. Midland is a "debt buyer." It paid a few cents for the account. Debt buyers rarely have all of the documents and information necessary to prevail in court.

My advice: Do not pay anything. Do not agree to pay anything. File an Answer. Include the Statute of Limitations as an affirmative defense. Apply for a Fee Waiver from the court. Then, serve a Demand for a Bill of Particulars. Then propound discovery, such as demands for production of documents, in the form specified in the Code of Civil Procedure. See section 2031.

If all of your assets are exempt from execution, you are "judgment-proof." Even if a judgment is entered against you, the creditor can collect exactly nothing. If they want to take your house, they must pay off all prior liens, then pay you, in cash, $125,000, for your homestead exemption, and then sell the house at auction. Creditors cannot attach disability benefits. If your wife needs all of her earnings to pay for the "necessities of life," such as food, shelter, transportation to work, medical, etc., they cannot effectively garnish any part of her wages.

You might want to spend a morning, or an afternoon, at a local law library. There may be one at the courthouse, or at a law school.

There really isn't anything you can "do" about it. First, unless you can provide a reason why you aren't liable for the debt, you owe it. So, there is no "defense" to the lawsuit. Therefore, they will be able to obtain a judgment.

Whether they can collect upon it, however, is another story. Your disability is exempt from collection, so they aren't going to collect anything from you that way. Unless you have any non-exempt assets available, you're basically judgment-proof. Your wife should keep her money in a separate account from yours - unless they try to sue her based upon the theory that she somehow benefited from the credit card (called the "necessities doctrine"), they cannot come after her. You should consult with a bankruptcy or debt attorney for specifics.
